BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: A critical avalanche situation will be encountered over a wide area. The large quantity of fresh snow as well as the often large wind slabs can be released easily or naturally.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
A lot of new snow above approximately 2000 m.
Avalanches can be released very easily and reach dangerously large size. This applies in particular above approximately 2000 m. From high-altitude starting zones the avalanches can reach the valleys and endanger transportation routes that are exposed.
At low and intermediate altitudes moist avalanches can penetrate even deep layers.
The conditions are very critical for backcountry touring.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area 100 to 150 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, fell in the last three days above approximately 2000 m. A lot of new snow in the high Alpine regions.
The sleet gave rise to a loss of strength within the snowpack over a wide area in particular at low and intermediate altitudes.

As a consequence of new snow and wind, sometimes large wind slabs formed.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs require caution, especially at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
New snow and wind slabs can be released easily and reach large size, especially at intermediate and high altitudes.
As a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation moist and wet avalanches are possible below approximately 2400 m.

The current avalanche situation calls for great caution and restraint.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area 50 to 70 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, fell in the last three days above approximately 2200 m. A lot of new snow in the high Alpine regions. Up to 2000 m rain has fallen in some regions.

As a consequence of new snow and wind, sometimes large wind slabs formed.

The surface of the snowpack will freeze to form a strong crust, after a clear night especially at low and intermediate altitudes.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: A critical avalanche situation will prevail.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: As a consequence of the ceasing of precipitation more frequent moist loose snow avalanches are to be expected, even large ones. On steep grassy slopes more medium-sized gliding avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The weather conditions as the day progresses will give rise to unfavourable bonding of the snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: As a consequence of warming during the day avalanches are to be expected as the day progresses, even quite large ones.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: A precarious avalanche situation will prevail.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The large quantity of fresh snow of the last few days as well as the wind slabs formed by the storm force wind can be released by a single winter sport participant in all aspects above approximately 2200 m. Large avalanches are possible. At intermediate altitudes these can release the wet old snow as well. The prevalence of avalanche prone locations and likelihood of triggering will increase with altitude. As a consequence of warming during the day and the solar radiation, the likelihood of slab avalanches being released will increase in particular on sunny slopes.

On steep grassy slopes medium-sized to large gliding avalanches are possible. This applies especially on steep sunny slopes below approximately 2600 m, including on steep shady slopes below approximately 2200 m. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.

As a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation numerous moist loose snow avalanches are to be expected as the day progresses, even medium-sized ones. This applies in particular on extremely steep sunny slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
40 to 120 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, fell in the last few days above approximately 2200 m. A lot of snow fell in the last few days over a wide area. This applies in particular at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions.
Fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are lying on soft layers in all aspects at elevated altitudes. The large quantity of fresh snow as well as the extensive wind slabs are poorly bonded with the old snowpack in some places in all aspects above approximately 2200 m. In some cases the various wind slabs have bonded still only poorly with each other and the old snowpack.
The rain gave rise to extreme and thorough wetting of the snowpack below approximately 2200 m.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Further decrease in danger of dry avalanches. High altitudes and the high Alpine regions: Wind slabs require caution. Below approximately 2600 m: Gliding snow requires caution. Only isolated wet loose snow avalanches are possible as the day progresses.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Gradual decrease in avalanche danger. New snow and wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
New snow and wind slabs can be released easily and reach large size, especially at intermediate and high altitudes.
As a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation moist and wet avalanches are possible below approximately 2400 m.

The current avalanche situation calls for great caution and restraint.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area 60 to 80 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, fell in the last three days above approximately 2000 m.
The sleet gave rise to a loss of strength within the snowpack over a wide area in particular at low and intermediate altitudes.
As a consequence of new snow and wind, sometimes large wind slabs formed in particular at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The large quantity of fresh snow as well as the often large wind slabs can be released easily or naturally.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
A lot of new snow above approximately 2000 m.
Avalanches can be released very easily and reach dangerously large size. This applies in particular above approximately 2000 m. From high-altitude starting zones the avalanches can as before reach low altitudes.
Below approximately 2400 m moist and wet avalanches are possible. Moist avalanches can penetrate even deep layers.
The conditions are very dangerous for backcountry touring and snowshoe hiking.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area 70 to 90 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, fell in the last three days above approximately 2000 m. A lot of new snow in the high Alpine regions.
The sleet gave rise to a loss of strength within the snowpack over a wide area in particular at low and intermediate altitudes.
As a consequence of new snow and wind, sometimes large wind slabs formed in particular at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The avalanche prone locations are numerous but are difficult to recognise. Ski touring and other off-piste activities, including snowshoe hiking, call for defensive route selection.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of wind from westerly directions, further wind slabs will form by Tuesday. Fresh and somewhat older wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in all aspects. This applies in particular on very steep slopes, as well as adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls.

Natural avalanches are further to be expected. The avalanches can be released in the new snow and wind slab layers and reach large size in some cases. In the typical avalanche paths in particular the avalanches can reach a long way.
As a consequence of solar radiation more moist and wet avalanches are possible as the day progresses. This applies in particular on very steep sunny slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
60 to 100 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen since Tuesday above approximately 2000 m. Here rain fell up to 2200 m.
The sometimes strong wind has transported the new snow significantly.
In some places new snow and wind slabs are lying on soft layers. The upper section of the snowpack is unfavourably layered.
Numerous medium-sized and large dry and wet avalanches have been released.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: As a consequence of warming during the day and the solar radiation, the likelihood of moist and wet avalanches being released will increase gradually.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The fresh snow and the extensive wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: In particular in gullies and bowls and behind abrupt changes in the terrain easily released wind slabs will form. Skiers can release avalanches very easily, including large ones. Remotely triggered and natural avalanches are probable.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The snowfall gave rise to unfavourable bonding of the snowpack over a wide area in particular on steep slopes. The fresh wind slabs are difficult even for the trained eye to recognise and to be assessed with care and prudence.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Fresh wind slabs are to be evaluated critically. Gliding snow requires caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The large quantity of fresh snow of the last few days as well as the wind slabs formed by the storm force to violent wind can be released by a single winter sport participant in all aspects above approximately 2200 m. Medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large avalanches are possible. At intermediate altitudes these can release the wet old snow as well. The prevalence of avalanche prone locations and likelihood of triggering will increase with altitude. As a consequence of warming during the day and the solar radiation, the likelihood of slab avalanches being released will increase in particular on sunny slopes.

On steep grassy slopes occasionally large gliding avalanches are possible. This applies especially on steep slopes below approximately 2600 m. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.

As a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation numerous moist loose snow avalanches are to be expected, even medium-sized ones. This applies in particular on extremely steep sunny slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
15 to 30 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen. This applies in particular above approximately 2200 m.
Fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are lying on soft layers in all aspects at elevated altitudes.
The rain gave rise to thorough wetting of the snowpack. Outgoing longwave radiation during the night will be reduced over a wide area.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Further decrease in danger of dry avalanches. High altitudes and the high Alpine regions: Wind slabs require caution. Below approximately 2600 m: Gliding snow requires caution. Only isolated wet loose snow avalanches are possible as the day progresses.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Dry and moist avalanches require caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation moist and wet avalanches are possible below approximately 2400 m.
New snow and wind slabs can be released and reach medium size, especially in high Alpine regions.

The current avalanche situation calls for caution.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
20 to 30 cm of snow fell in the last three days above approximately 2200 m. Up to 2100 m rain has fallen.

The surface of the snowpack will freeze to form a strong crust, after a clear night especially at low and intermediate altitudes.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: A sometimes precarious avalanche situation will prevail.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The large quantity of fresh snow of the last few days as well as the sometimes large wind slabs formed by the storm force to violent wind can be released by a single winter sport participant in all aspects above approximately 2200 m. Large avalanches are possible. At intermediate altitudes these can release the wet old snow as well. The prevalence of avalanche prone locations and likelihood of triggering will increase with altitude. As a consequence of warming during the day and the solar radiation, the likelihood of slab avalanches being released will increase in particular on sunny slopes.

On steep grassy slopes medium-sized to large gliding avalanches are possible. This applies especially on steep sunny slopes below approximately 2600 m, including on steep shady slopes below approximately 2400 m. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.

As a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation numerous moist loose snow avalanches are to be expected as the day progresses, even medium-sized ones. This applies in particular on extremely steep sunny slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
A lot of snow fell in the last few days over a wide area. This applies in particular at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions.
Fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are lying on soft layers in all aspects at elevated altitudes. In some cases the various wind slabs have bonded still only poorly together.
The rain gave rise to extreme and thorough wetting of the snowpack below approximately 2200 m. Outgoing longwave radiation during the night will be reduced over a wide area.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Further decrease in danger of dry avalanches. High altitudes and the high Alpine regions: Wind slabs require caution. Below approximately 2600 m: Gliding snow requires caution. Only isolated wet loose snow avalanches are possible as the day progresses.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Fresh wind slabs are to be evaluated critically. Wet and gliding snow require caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The large quantity of fresh snow of the last few days as well as the wind slabs formed by the storm force to violent wind can be released by a single winter sport participant in all aspects above approximately 2400 m. Medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large avalanches are possible. At intermediate altitudes these can release the wet old snow as well. The prevalence of avalanche prone locations and likelihood of triggering will increase with altitude. As a consequence of warming during the day and the solar radiation, the likelihood of slab avalanches being released will increase in particular on sunny slopes.

On steep grassy slopes occasionally large gliding avalanches are possible. This applies especially on steep slopes below approximately 2600 m. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.

As a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation numerous moist loose snow avalanches are to be expected, even medium-sized ones. This applies in particular on extremely steep sunny slopes below approximately 2400 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
15 to 30 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen. This applies in particular above approximately 2400 m.
Fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are lying on soft layers in all aspects at elevated altitudes.
The rain gave rise to thorough wetting of the snowpack. Outgoing longwave radiation during the night will be reduced over a wide area.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Further decrease in danger of dry avalanches. High altitudes and the high Alpine regions: Wind slabs require caution. Below approximately 2600 m: Gliding snow requires caution. Only isolated wet loose snow avalanches are possible as the day progresses.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The avalanche prone locations are difficult to recognise. Ski touring and other off-piste activities, including snowshoe hiking, call for defensive route selection.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of wind from westerly directions, further wind slabs will form by Tuesday. Fresh and somewhat older wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in all aspects. This applies in particular on very steep slopes, as well as adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls.

Natural avalanches are further to be expected. The avalanches can be released in the new snow and wind slab layers and reach large size in some cases. As a consequence of solar radiation more moist and wet avalanches are possible as the day progresses. This applies in particular on very steep sunny slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
50 to 80 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen since Tuesday above approximately 2000 m. Here rain fell up to 2100 m.
The sometimes strong wind has transported the new snow significantly.
In some places new snow and wind slabs are lying on soft layers. The upper section of the snowpack is unfavourably layered.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Dry and moist avalanches are possible in some places.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The danger of moist and wet avalanches will increase during the day. In addition the wind slabs should be taken into account.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: As a consequence of the precipitation moist loose snow avalanches are to be expected, in particular medium-sized ones. Fresh and somewhat older wind slabs can be released easily by a single winter sport participant above the tree line. On very steep grassy slopes more gliding avalanches are possible. The prevalence of the avalanche prone locations will increase with altitude. On steep grassy slopes more medium-sized gliding avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Over a wide area 2 to 50 cm of snow will fall until Monday above approximately 1800 m. The rain will give rise as the day progresses to a loss of strength within the snowpack. The wind will be strong to storm force. In the vicinity of peaks wind slabs will form.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: As a consequence of warming during the day avalanches are to be expected as the day progresses, in particular medium-sized ones.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The new snow and wind slabs represent the main danger. In the regions exposed to heavier precipitation the avalanche prone locations are more prevalent and larger. As a consequence of the rain moist and wet avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The fresh snow as well as the wind slabs must be evaluated with care and prudence at intermediate and high altitudes. This applies in particular in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation.
The rain will give rise to thorough wetting of the snowpack over a wide area in particular at low and intermediate altitudes. Gradual increase in danger of moist and wet avalanches as a consequence of the precipitation. In all aspects large and, in isolated cases, very large avalanches are possible. Individual gliding avalanches can also occur. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in all aspects.
Avalanches can be released, even by a single winter sport participant.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: In the last few days wind slabs formed. The new snow and wind slabs are bonding poorly with the old snowpack in many places. The weather conditions will give rise to thorough wetting of the snowpack in particular at low and intermediate altitudes. Weak layers exist in the snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Over a wide area light precipitation.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Gliding snow requires caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
On steep grassy slopes small to medium-sized gliding avalanches are possible. Areas with glide cracks are to be avoided.

As a consequence of warming during the day and solar radiation moist loose snow avalanches are possible. This applies in particular on extremely steep sunny slopes.

The fresh snow of the last few days as well as the wind slabs formed by the storm force to violent wind can be released by a single winter sport participant in some cases at elevated altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
In some regions 15 to 30 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen. This applies in particular at elevated altitudes.
The rain gave rise to thorough wetting of the snowpack. Outgoing longwave radiation during the night will be reduced over a wide area.
Fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are lying on soft layers in particular on shady slopes at elevated altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Gliding snow requires caution. Only isolated wet loose snow avalanches are possible as the day progresses. Further decrease in danger of dry avalanches.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The fresh snow and the sometimes deep wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The fresh wind slabs must be evaluated with care and prudence in all aspects above approximately 2500 m. As a consequence of the precipitation medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large wet avalanches are possible below approximately 2500 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The sleet will give rise as the day progresses to rapid and thorough wetting of the old snowpack below approximately 2500 m. The fresh wind slabs are difficult even for the trained eye to recognise and to be assessed with care and prudence.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The sleet will give rise as the day progresses to rapid and thorough wetting of the old snowpack below approximately 1700 m.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The avalanche prone locations are very rare and are easy to recognise.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The old snowpack will be generally wet all the way through.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wet snow represents the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: As a consequence of the ceasing of precipitation small and, in isolated cases, medium-sized moist and wet avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: 20 to 40 cm of snow has fallen above approximately 2000 m. Sunshine and high temperatures will give rise as the day progresses to a loss of strength within the snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: At low and intermediate altitudes a low danger of gliding avalanches and moist snow slides will be encountered in some localities.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wet snow slides and avalanches are possible in isolated cases. Mostly these are small.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Individual mostly small wet snow slides and avalanches are possible above approximately 1900 m. In gullies and bowls a sometimes precarious avalanche situation will be encountered in some localities.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Below approximately 1900 m hardly any snow is lying. The older wind slabs are to be found especially in gullies and bowls and at high altitudes.
